definition: (of a person) to return to the fray after a period of inactivity/to jump back into the thick of things/(of sth that was once popular) to be resurrected/to make a comeback
heavy/serious/to attach importance to
to repeat/repetition/again/re-/classifier: layer

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)
river/CL:條|条[tiao2],道[dao4]
surname Jiang
lake/CL:個|个[ge4],片[pian4]

sentences.english: We will see the super soft compound in use again, how difficult will tyre management be?
sentences.chinese: 超软光头胎重出江湖，对于轮胎分配有什么困难？

sentences.english: After having stopped acting for many years, he made his reappearance in a comic role.
sentences.chinese: 他在息影多年后重出江湖，准备参加一部喜剧的拍摄。

definition: see 重出江湖 [chong2 chu1 jiang1 hu2]
lit. to wash one's hands in a gold basin (idiom)/fig. to abandon the life of an outlaw
to leave the mountain (of a hermit)/to come out of obscurity to a government job/to take a leading position
to vanish without trace (idiom)/to lie low
to adjust one's head and turn one's face (idiom); cosmetic changes/Despite superficially new policies, the substance remains unchanged.
to retire (from society, esp. from politics)/to vanish
lit. to return to office after living as a hermit on Mount Dongshan (idiom); fig. to make a comeback
lit. to return in a swirl of dust (idiom)/fig. to regroup and come back even stronger/to make a comeback
(of property) to change owners/(of sovereignty, political power etc) to change hands
to mend one's ways (idiom)/to turn over a new leaf
treasure knife does not age (idiom); old but still vigorous
lit. to wash one's heart and renew one's face (idiom); to repent sincerely and mend one's mistaken ways/to turn over a new leaf
to return
(argot) gang leader
lit. to proclaim oneself hegemon/to take a leading role/to build a personal fiefdom
to make up and go on stage (idiom); to embark on a career (esp. in politics or crime)
